description: From Middle English martir, from Old English martyr, itself a borrowing from Ecclesiastical Latin martyr, from Ancient Greek μάρτυρ (mártur), later form of μάρτυς (mártus, “witness”).

entries.meaning: One who willingly accepts being put to death for adhering openly to one's religious beliefs; notably, saints canonized after martyrdom.
examples: Saint Stephen was the first Christian martyr.

entries.meaning: (by extension) One who sacrifices their life, station, or something of great personal value, for the sake of principle or to sustain a cause.
(with a prepositional phrase of cause) One who suffers greatly and/or constantly, even involuntarily.
examples: Stan is a martyr to arthritis, Chris a martyr to Stan's endless moaning about it.

verbs.description: martyr (third-person singular simple present martyrs, present participle martyring, simple past and past participle martyred)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To make someone into a martyr by putting them to death for adhering to, or acting in accordance with, some belief, especially religious; to sacrifice on account of faith or profession.

examples: Some religious and other minorities were martyred until extinction.
